result.execSummary:
The defendant Kayla Dae Johnvin was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Operate Firearm While Intoxicated, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 941.20(1)(b).
  • Impersonating a Peace Officer, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.70(1)(a).
  • OWI (1st). This is not a criminal offense and results only in a money penalty for this offense.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

All available enforcement actions will be used to collect all debt. Attorney fees to be determined.

Defendant pleads guilty to counts 2, 5, and 6.  Court accepts plea and finds defendant guilty.  Argument by State.  Argument by defense.  Defendant addresses the court.

Count 2 - $811.50 forfeiture with 60 days to pay, 6 month revocation of drivers license, AODA and comply with recommended follow-up treatment, costs.  Revocation stayed until 7/25/16.  
Count 5 & 6 -30 days jail on each count consecutive to begin today, four days jail credit with huber/homemaker and good time, and court costs.

Court relates Case 15CF522 has a co-defendant and both defendants must request substitution of Judge.
Court recesses for Clerk to check if motion has been received from co-defendant.  No motion has been received from co-defendant to date.  
Court resumes.  Court relates motion for substitution should have been made by co-defendant at intake.  
Court receives Motion for Substitution of Judge via Fax for co-defendant Case 15CM510.
Argument by Attorney Weber on substitution and also questions if traffic and refusal hearing should track with criminal case.  
Argument by State for substitution of Judge by co-defendant due to timeliness and relates refusal hearing is set for today.
Court relates co-defendant's substitution motion on Case 15CM510 was not timely.
Court relates complications of severance of cases and substitution.  Court denies motion of Substitution of Judge and denies request for citations to be severed from criminal case.
